subtitle: Hello, I'm Jeffrey Mishlove. I'm back once again after a long trip to Dallas and
between another trip, I'll be leaving tomorrow for Chicago. But, today I'm here
and I thought I would talk about the Sheep-Goat effect in parapsychology. This
is actually one of the most consistently reported and peculiar effects in
parapsychology. Well, it's not peculiar in one sense. It's not peculiar because it
represents the concept that parapsychological phenomena, unlike
other psychological phenomena, they're influenced by all sorts of psychological
variables that we understand. Now, why is it peculiar, because... Well, I should define
the Sheep-Goat effect before we get too much further. It's very simple. The Sheep-
Goat effect was first reported in 1945 by Professor Gertrude Schmeidler, a
psychologist at the City College of New York. It's basically this: if you
believe you can perform in an ESP test, chances are your scores are going to be
above chance. In those days it was simple card guessing tests. If you
believe that you just can't do ESP or if ESP doesn't even exist,
you're likely to score at chance or maybe even below chance. So, in effect,
it's saying that your belief system affects your ability to perform in an
ESP test. Now, the bugaboo is this, and why I called it peculiar, is because the
skeptics use that as an argument to invalidate all the
research they say, because all the good results are reported by people who
believe in ESP then it's not trustworthy. Well, that's a spurious argument from a
scientific point of view because you really have to
look at the scientific controls as to whether or not it's a legitimate finding. This
is a finding that has been reported over and over and over again. There are
probably 70 or 80 published studies that attempt to confirm the Sheep-Goat effect.
But there are many nuances. For example, it could be that sheep score high and
goats score at chance or it could be that sheep score at chance and goats score
significantly below chance. What does that mean, when someone scores
significantly below chance? We call it psi-missing. In effect it means that
at some level inside of their psyche, they are getting the correct information
but then they block it and choose something else. An interesting study
I talked about earlier published in a book called Executive ESP, showed
that business executives whose companies were losing money scored significantly
below chance on a test of precognition. So, that's an example of psi-missing.
It tends to be the case that goats do score below chance, the
hardcore skeptics in particular. So, we know that your attitude affects your
performance. Well, that's not anything new. That's true across the board in
hundreds of different kinds of phenomena. The famous American inventor and
entrepreneur Henry Ford once put it very succinctly, "Whether you believe you can
or you can't, you are correct." That's a quote from Henry Ford. So, in the
realm of parapsychology, there are of course many levels of belief. For example,
I might believe that ESP exists but have no confidence that
I myself can exhibit ESP in a particular test. Or, I might believe that I can't do
it generally but today I feel really charged up. Today, I know it's
going to work. I'll speak for myself. For example,
I don't advertise myself as a psychic. I don't really claim to have it under
control all the time, although I know in the "In Presence" series I keep referring
to the notion of telepathic transmission. Something does seem to be welling up
in me in that regard. But normally I don't talk about these things. I'm a
radio host, a TV host, a scholar. I don't have a shingle out as a psychic. I don't
purport to be. I would never charge money for performing as a psychic. That's not
me. But there was a time, I've talked about it, in 1972 when I was really
concerned about the whole direction my life was going to take, when I had a
certain feeling, I knew that an answer to all my agonizing and struggling over this
question was going to come in a dream that evening. I've never had that
experience before or after, but that day I knew it was going to happen with
absolute certainty and then it did. And sometimes, I guess you could say it's
just intuition, you know you can do it. Now the psychologist Mihaly
Csikszentmihalyi, who has written a book called Flow and writes about creativity,
suggests that one of the best ways to develop your self-confidence with regard
to your creative abilities and your ability to accomplish things is to
take on projects that stretch you just a little bit but that you know you can do.
If you try to take on a project that is way, way beyond your experience, well,
chances of failure will be higher than if you take on a
project that stretches you a little, but you're confident you can do this. I think
the same thing is true in ESP, but it's a little tricky because it's not as if we
can give you a mechanistic recipe for how to perform in an ESP task. Some
things are simpler than others. But, I suppose as my good friend Russell
Targ once said, any kind of psychic functioning is like a miracle. How did
that happen? We still don't really know exactly. I say that as a
parapsychologist. What I mean to say is we don't know in the sense that it
doesn't fit any of our existing well accepted scientific models. But, to be
honest, there are other models to draw upon.
There is esoteric lore and not just lore but esoteric philosophy going back to
ancient times. There is a lot of knowledge that
we can draw upon, there are traditions and shamanism and yoga and so on that
offer a lot of guidelines, a lot of guidance as to how one can begin to
accumulate experience and knowledge. Sometimes, in the parapsychological
domain people have spontaneous experiences and that gives them
the confidence to know whether or not they can perform in a particular task in a
particular day, that at least they have some confidence that the phenomenon is
real. I should say the phenomena are real, it's a plural word, that the phenomenon
is real. The main point I'd like to make is that working on your attitude
can make a big difference not only in your success, and if you were a subject in
a parapsychology laboratory, which will probably only happen to very few of
the viewers, but if you're interested in being able to apply psi in your daily
life, or if you're interested in shall we just say, manifesting, if you're
interested in doing, creating, accomplishing things in the world at
large, working on your attitude, your belief system is important to the
extent that you have the ability to draw upon confidence that you can perform.
Call it the X-factor rather than psi. If you have the X-factor working for you
and you have some confidence that it can work, you're likely to do at least a
little bit better. Now, how can you make really good use of this information? How
can you build up your confidence to do something that is so intangible as extrasensory
perception? I would say that there's one simple word: practice. Give it a try,
experiment, and don't give up if you have a few failures. You know, the truth of the
matter is, in almost any human endeavor if you start out you're going to fumble
at first. I once had a business guru who put it this way. He said, "Anything worth
doing is worth doing poorly, because chances are you're going to struggle a
little bit at first." Although, the irony is in the ESP realm, it's almost the
opposite. We have a beginner's luck effect, the novelty, the excitement of
doing something for the first time, it actually can be quite easy. I know of
any number of cases of people the first time they try it, they startle
themselves at how well they do. So, the tricky thing is the second, third, fourth,
fifth, sixth time. That's when it becomes harder because you've got to integrate
it. We live in a culture that doesn't give
us as much support as it might for integrating it. Well, I'm going to leave
you with those thoughts. I have to tell you because I'm still traveling, the
schedule for "In Presence" monologues it's going to be a bit sporadic, but I intend
to do my best to keep it going. You may have noticed that while I haven't
been putting up "In Presence" monologues as frequently, I have been putting up
video nuggets. So, I hope you enjoy those and give some thought to what you can do
to work with your own inner attitude, not just towards psi or parapsychology or
what I'm now calling the X-factor, but to anything worthwhile that you wish to
accomplish in your life. What are the steps that you can take to build up your
self confidence? Thank you for being with me.
